title: Presidential Pardon Scam: New Questions Surround Matt Argall and Who is Valerie Haney?
body: When Bloomberg reported in August 2025 that businessman Matt Argall attempted to engineer a $30 million presidential pardon deal connected to cryptocurrency entrepreneur Roger Ver, the story exposed a remarkable blend of hubris and desperation. The pardon never reached Donald Trump’s desk, but the failed scheme is now prompting a far deeper line of inquiry: who, exactly, helped Argall maneuver through Washington’s political landscape, and to what extent were they complicit? Federal investigators, according to sources familiar with the matter, are no longer focusing solely on Argall’s own activities. Instead, they are mapping the ecosystem around him—friends, associates, and companions who may have provided credibility, introductions, or logistical support in the capital. For a man long associated with failed ventures, unpaid debts, and grandiose claims, Argall’s ability to embed himself in high-level discussions raises as many questions as the pardon scheme itself. The Haney Connection Valerie Haney, Matt Argall (Source: Haney/TikTok, December 24, 2024) Central to this broader probe is Valerie Haney, Argall’s longtime girlfriend and frequent companion at political and business gatherings. Haney’s background is in Hollywood, where she once worked as the personal assistant to actress Leah Remini. It was during that time that she crossed paths with Argall, a connection that soon drew her into his ventures. Leah Remini, Valerie Haney (Source: Haney/Instagram, June 29, 2024) Multiple sources confirm Haney’s presence at meetings in Washington as early as 2022, including sessions where Argall and crypto entrepreneur Brock Pierce met with representatives of Roger Ver. Her presence is not, at this stage, proof of active involvement. But investigators are keenly aware of how proximity can translate into influence, and whether Haney’s repeated appearance at high-level meetings may have helped Argall project a veneer of legitimacy he otherwise lacked. The question is not whether she brokered deals, but whether her participation—intended or not—enabled Argall to open doors he could not have opened alone. The Pardon-for-Sale Scheme The mechanics of the scheme, as first detailed by Bloomberg, centered on Argall’s attempt to profit from Ver’s legal and regulatory troubles. Ver, once hailed as “Bitcoin Jesus,” was facing mounting legal pressures abroad. Argall, leveraging his connection to Brock Pierce, dangled the prospect of presidential clemency—a commodity worth millions if delivered. What remains murky is how far this offer progressed, who in Washington took it seriously, and whether others in Argall’s circle stood to benefit financially. Investigators are particularly interested in who was present at the meetings and whether their participation suggested awareness, endorsement, or financial expectation. Haney’s confirmation as being in the room has sharpened that line of inquiry. Expanding the Probe At present, federal authorities have declined to publicly define the scope of the investigation. But interviews with individuals close to the matter suggest a widening lens. Argall is unlikely to have acted entirely alone. For years, he has cultivated an entourage of aides, acquaintances, and hangers-on. Now, each of those associations is being scrutinized for signs of enabling behavior—whether deliberate or inadvertent. One investigator summarized the issue bluntly: “It’s not just about what Argall was promising. It’s about who else showed up, who else went along with it, and who else thought they might cash in.” That framing highlights the challenge investigators face. Untangling Argall’s web means distinguishing between those who were duped by proximity and those who actively aided his efforts. The former suggests gullibility; the latter, potential complicity. A Broader Warning The unraveling of Argall’s pardon gambit is more than a personal downfall. It is a case study in how Washington’s ecosystem of access, image, and personal relationships can be exploited by opportunists. Argall’s credibility was not built on achievement, but on appearances—on the ability to surround himself with figures, companions, and settings that suggested influence. For Valerie Haney, the unanswered question is whether her role was incidental or integral. Her proximity to Argall during crucial discussions means she is now part of the story, whether she intended to be or not. The broader warning is clear: scandals in Washington rarely involve a single rogue actor. They almost always reveal a constellation of associates, enablers, and beneficiaries. As the probe into Argall widens, it is becoming less about one man’s failed scheme and more about the network that allowed him to move freely through the corridors of power. title: China’s EV insurance business is losing a lot of money because repair costs are too high
body: China’s once-booming electric vehicle (EV) insurance business is fast becoming a money-losing sector. Claims are growing faster than expected, and insurers are losing billions of yuan annually. The issue is that EV adoption in the country has outpaced insurers’ antiquated tools to price risk. As a result, one of the world’s most advanced EV markets has become a battleground for insurers. China has the world’s largest number of EVs on the road. More than 20 million new energy vehicles (NEVs), including pure electric cars and plug-in hybrids, are registered nationwide. And sales continue to soar, with EVs now outselling gasoline cars in several cities. Yet behind the surge, insurance statistics paint a chilling reality. Owners of electric vehicles, many younger than motorists who pilot traditional internal combustion, are roughly twice as likely to file claims on their policies. Their vehicles are also much pricier to repair. Batteries account for roughly a third of a car’s value and are most at risk. These units are mounted under the floor and can more easily be damaged by speed bumps or road detritus. And new ones aren’t cheap; sometimes, replacing one is more than it would cost to repair the entire rest of the car combined. Specialized components like sensors and chips have become more expensive and difficult to find. And often repairs can only be made by authorized service centers, many at Tesla-certified body shops, where costs are all too expensive. In China, insurers lost 5.7 billion yuan ($802 million) on underwriting EV policies in 2024 alone, according to the China Association of Actuaries. Total premium income was almost 141 billion yuan, but claims and repair costs outweighed profits. Qin Lu, the chief executive officer of Greater China at Aon Plc, said insurers could not fully distinguish between car brands, models, and loss patterns, adding that the sector remained challenging. He predicted it could take about three more years before businesses could break even. Regulators attempt fixes as losses pile up The mounting losses have drawn the attention of regulators. In January 2025, China issued its first insurance guide for EVs and plug-in hybrids. The goal is to create uniform coverage, lower repair costs, and pressure carmakers to work with insurers. Automakers are packing their vehicles with copious amounts of data about battery health, driving patterns, and vehicle usage. However, insurers have had little access to it, complicating their ability to build accurate risk models. The new rules promote the sharing of data across industries to allow insurers to price policies more equitably. The government also initiated an online service called “Easy to Insure,” which matches up EV owners with insurance coverage. The platform has helped cover over 500,000 vehicles with policies with a combined value of nearly 495 billion yuan. body: BitcoinWorld Urgent Alert: Bitcoin Price Fall Sees BTC Plunge Below $114,000 The cryptocurrency market is once again showing its dynamic nature as an unexpected Bitcoin price fall has caught many investors by surprise. According to recent market monitoring, BTC has notably dipped below the significant $114,000 mark. Currently, Bitcoin is trading at approximately $113,976.55 on the Binance USDT market, reflecting a moment of heightened scrutiny for digital asset holders. This recent drop signals a crucial period for the world’s leading cryptocurrency, prompting questions about market stability and future trajectories. Many are now observing closely to understand the underlying factors contributing to this sudden shift. What Triggered This Urgent Bitcoin Price Fall? When a significant Bitcoin price fall occurs, it rarely happens without a confluence of factors. Several elements might be at play, influencing investor sentiment and market dynamics. One primary driver could be widespread profit-taking, where large holders decide to sell off portions of their assets after a period of gains, creating downward pressure. Macroeconomic Headwinds: Broader economic concerns, such as inflation fears or changes in interest rates, often push investors away from riskier assets like cryptocurrencies. Technical Breakdown: From a technical analysis perspective, BTC might have broken key support levels, triggering automated sell orders and exacerbating the decline. Regulatory Uncertainty: Ongoing discussions or new announcements regarding cryptocurrency regulations in major economies can also introduce volatility and contribute to a Bitcoin price fall . Understanding these potential catalysts is essential for comprehending the current market behavior and anticipating future movements. The Immediate Impact of BTC’s Price Drop An abrupt Bitcoin price fall below a significant threshold like $114,000 inevitably sends ripples across the entire crypto ecosystem. For individual investors, this can lead to varying emotional and financial responses. Those holding BTC might experience paper losses, while potential buyers could see this as an opportunity to enter the market at a lower price point. Moreover, the performance of Bitcoin often influences altcoins, with many typically following BTC’s trend. Therefore, a dip in Bitcoin’s value frequently translates to broader market corrections. The immediate impact also includes: Increased Volatility: Price swings become more pronounced, making short-term trading riskier. Shift in Market Sentiment: A general sense of caution or even fear can spread, impacting decision-making. Liquidation Events: Traders using leverage might face liquidation if their positions fall below margin requirements. Observing these immediate reactions helps in gauging the market’s resilience and potential recovery paths. Navigating Volatility: What Should Investors Do Amidst a Bitcoin Price Fall? During periods of a significant Bitcoin price fall , maintaining a clear strategy is paramount. Panic selling often leads to regret, while informed decisions can help protect or even grow your portfolio. Here are some actionable insights: Do Your Own Research (DYOR): Before making any decisions, thoroughly research the market conditions and potential future outlooks. Do not rely solely on headlines. Consider Dollar-Cost Averaging (DCA): Instead of investing a lump sum, DCA involves investing a fixed amount regularly, regardless of the price. This strategy can mitigate risk during volatile periods. Re-evaluate Your Portfolio: A market dip is an excellent time to assess your risk tolerance and ensure your portfolio allocation aligns with your long-term financial goals. Focus on Long-Term Holdings (HODL): For those with a long-term conviction in Bitcoin’s value, a temporary Bitcoin price fall might be seen as a mere blip on the radar, making HODLing a viable strategy. Remember, the crypto market is inherently volatile. Educating yourself and making calculated moves are crucial during these times. The recent Bitcoin price fall below $114,000 serves as a powerful reminder of the dynamic and often unpredictable nature of the cryptocurrency market. While such dips can be unsettling, they are also an integral part of its evolution. Whether driven by profit-taking, macroeconomic shifts, or technical factors, understanding these movements is key to navigating the digital asset landscape. Ultimately, the resilience of Bitcoin and the broader crypto market will be tested, but its history suggests a capacity for recovery. Investors are encouraged to stay informed, adopt prudent strategies, and view market fluctuations with a balanced perspective. The journey of cryptocurrency continues, full of both challenges and opportunities. Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) Q1: Is a Bitcoin price fall common? A1: Yes, price volatility, including significant drops, is a common characteristic of the cryptocurrency market. Bitcoin has experienced numerous corrections throughout its history. Q2: What does “trading at $113,976.55 on the Binance USDT market” mean? A2: This indicates the current price of Bitcoin (BTC) against Tether (USDT), a stablecoin, on the Binance exchange. USDT is pegged to the US dollar, so this effectively means BTC is trading for approximately $113,976.55 US dollars. Q3: Should I sell my Bitcoin when its price falls? A3: This depends entirely on your personal financial situation, risk tolerance, and investment strategy. Many long-term investors choose to “HODL” (hold on for dear life) during dips, while others might sell to cut losses or reallocate funds. It’s crucial to do your own research (DYOR) before making any investment decisions. Q4: How can I stay updated on Bitcoin’s price movements? A4: You can monitor Bitcoin’s price through various cryptocurrency exchanges, financial news websites, and dedicated market tracking platforms. Setting up price alerts can also be helpful. Q5: Does a Bitcoin price fall affect other cryptocurrencies? A5: Often, yes. Bitcoin’s performance typically influences the broader altcoin market.
